posts.edge_media_to_caption:
Last night's dinner table at my + @thepineapplechef's #FirstWeEat photography workshop here at @lacannonerie near Cognac. The table was set by @mimiconfetti with @carron.paris ceramics handmade here in France, the most beautiful robin's egg blue linens from @linenfox, local flowers from @fairyfleur1, and lots of French wine and food (of course üòã)
.
I can't even begin to describe how magical this place is. @lacannonerie is run by Shelley and her husband and they have been lovingly restoring this place for the last 8 years. They have little books around the property showing the transformation from when they first found it to today, and boy if I thought my home renovations were hard work, it was definitely a wake up call flipping through that! üõ†
.
It just goes to show that when something falls into disrepair through time or by accident, all is not lost. Instead it creates an opportunity for people to create beauty anew, and show that humanity and all the art + texture + love that comes with it can persevere. So very grateful to be here surrounded by so many passionate and creative people üíö
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

I have a little confession to make, I've shot and developed recipes for 5 blog posts to share with you all, but between getting the garden ready for spring before my trip (which involved weeding hundreds of fennel seedlings that came up after my fennel self-seeded last year. UGH.), working on 'work' stuff, and packing, I just haven't been able to write them up properly yet. The recipes are *so* good and I really want to share them with you all, and I eventually will, but it will most likely be in May once I'm back home and settled. üè°
.
In the meantime, though, I'll still be sharing things here on instagram (albeit no recipes), but know that once they're up on the blog I'll be shouting it from the rooftops here! üòâ Also, you can follow along with all the workshop goodness I'm up to in France with @thepineapplechef and @mimiconfetti in my stories ‚ú®
.
And in case you weren't sure, spring has definitely arrived! The girls were laying up a storm due to the longer days, and I'm definitely enjoying the boon of eggs in the kitchen. It's so funny to watch them scratching around and pecking at every little green sprout and granule on the ground, I only wish I could make them target those pesky fennel sprouts so I wouldn't have to crawl around on my hands and knees pulling them out one by one üò¨üå±üòÇ
.
.
.
.
.
.

So incredibly honored that my book #FirstWeEat was nominated for the @iacppix award for best American cookbook alongside @doriegreenspan and @cheftoddrichards. As seasonal living becomes more mainstream, my hope is that my book continues to provide a source of delicious, simple, fresh, and seasonally based meals for years to come. üíö
.
We only have this one Earth, and if we continue to build our meals around food imported from the other side of the world on a daily basis (I'm looking at you, coconuts), it cannot stand the carbon footprint much longer. Eating locally and seasonally is THE single best thing you can do for your body, your community, your taste buds, and our planet. If you're intrigued but don't know where to begin, start going to your nearest farmers market. üë©üèª‚Äçüåæ
.
Lots of local growers will be there and you'll be able to have some of the tastiest produce, ever, and even local dairy, fish, or meat depending on the vendors and local farms. I promise you'll have a wonderful time and your taste buds will be very happy! üòã
.
You can also join a CSA, which is basically a local farm subscription box. Just Google your town name and 'CSA' to see if there's any in your area. I'm coming up on year three as a member of @andreabemis' CSA and looooove the delicious veggies her farm provides us with! I talk about allllllll the ways to eat seasonally & locally in my book, so definitely grab a copy if you'd like to learn more! üòäüí°üìó
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

Yesterday was a whirlwind of packing up my bags again and getting everything in place before I left. I transplanted 82 tomato seedlings until the sun set and I had to finish doing it outside with my @barebonesliving camping lamp üòÇ BUT I did get them all moved into bigger containers, so all the squinting and the two tomato casualties were worth it.
.
This morning I'm heading to France to meet with @thepineapplechef to host our photography workshop at @lacannonerie around the Cognac area, and I am SO excited to see her and meet all our guests! You can follow along in my Instagram stories for some fun travel adventures üòä Wishing you all a wonderful Friday!!
.
P.S. I have been a terrible blogger and still haven't finished the post for this cheesecake yet, but I'm hoping to be able to share it with you within the next couple weeks because it was SO bonkers good and you should all be able to make + enjoy it. Will share soon!!!! ‚ô•Ô∏è
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

When we first moved into this house 5 years ago, this clematis vine was growing in all sorts of directions‚Äîit completely covered the garden window behind me in the photo, and had even started growing into the pear tree along the side of the house. My mom came over and we trimmed it back, and over the past few years Jeremy and I have been pruning it more and more to help encourage new growth + blossoms. üåø
.
The vine had SO much energy and just wanted to grow and grow and grow, so last spring I built a little arch out of downed branches over the stairway going up to our house and lined it with some mesh in hopes that the clematis vine would take to it. I helped train the vine, little by little, and wove the new growth into the archway, helping give all its energy and resources a purposeful direction to grow. And grow it did! ü§©
.
By the end of last summer, the vine had made it all the way across the arch, and this spring it rewarded us with the most beautiful flurry of fragrant white flowers. Walking under it every time I leave or enter the house is the most wonderful feeling‚Äîit just reminds me how much we can grow + how much beauty we can create when we have a sense of purpose and direction. üß≠
.
Don't be afraid to let go of the things that don't work for you anymore and don't make you happy sometimes cutting off the meandering old growth and focusing in on purposeful new growth can result in something wonderful. And I'm not just talking about plants! üòâüíöüí´
.
.
.
.
.
.
#mygarden #instagardeners #gardenlove #gardendesign #gardeninspiration #inmygarden #tr√§dg√•rd #jardin #hage #giardino #outdoorliving #outdoorlife #instagarden #loves_garden #instagardenlovers #Forageandharvest #botanical #growsomethinggreen #growyourownfood #garden_explorers #garden_styles #organicgardening #folkscenery #forageandharvest #foragedbouquet #floweroftheday #flashesofdelight #pursuepretty #petitejoys

posts.edge_media_to_caption:
With the fast pace of life and the constant pressure to achieve achieve achieve, so often we focus on what we need to improve and acquire instead of focusing on the wonderful things we already have. I'm not going to sell you on growing your following or talk blindly about doubling profit margins, but instead I am asking you to sit down and think.
.
Think about what you are grateful for. What in your life makes you happy, warm, and full. Focus in on that, and try and appreciate that thing while in the act of doing it.
.
So often we go through the motions of the things that we enjoy, like cooking dinner or hugging our partners or drinking a cup of coffee, without pausing to consciously appreciate it and acknowledge the pleasure of the moment. Life's too short to rush through. ‚ô•Ô∏è
.
Instead, slow down, savor the taste, and remember the little things that make life worth living. I'm grateful for my husband, my family, newly sprouted plants, the raindrops on my house's warbled old window after a storm, and the steam on my face when I'm about to dive into a hot cup of tea. What about you? üçµü§∏üèæ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüòç
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

Today I‚Äôm participating in the #CarbonaraChallenge with @BarillaUS in honor of #CarbonaraDay and sharing a little photo of myself diving into this insanely good bucatini carbonara! You can find the recipe via the link in my profile, I highly recommend making some today and participating in the challenge yourself! Joining the challenge is *super* easy‚Äîjust make your favorite Carbonara recipe for your family and friends, post the dish on social media and challenge your friends to take the #CarbonaraChallenge, too! üçù
.
I can‚Äôt emphasize enough how delicious this pasta is, the sauce is made from a mixture of egg yolks, freshly grated romano and parmesan cheese, black pepper, pan-fried pancetta, caramelized onions, and fresh basil‚Äîif that doesn‚Äôt spell crazy tasty for you, I don‚Äôt know what does üòç
.
Make sure to whip up a big batch for yourself and your friends and family today and share it with the #CarbonaraChallenge hashtag! I can‚Äôt wait to see all the delicious carbonara in my feed today, woohoo!!! üòãüçùüëåüèº
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

Heading back home again tomorrow, and can't wait to see all that's changed in the garden while I was gone. Jeremy has been watching over my little tomato starts for me, and I am SO excited to see how much they've grown in the past week. üòÜ
.
With all the traveling I do, there really is nothing as grounding as putting my hands back in the earth in my own backyard to help me feel right at home again. Studies have actually shown that the microbes in soil help stimulate serotonin production when they come in contact with the skin, so it's no wonder that I'm happiest when I'm covered with dirt üòÇ
.
One of my favorite quotes of all time comes from Margaret Atwood, and it says 'In the spring, at the end of the day, you should smell like dirt.' And I find that to be quite fitting üåø Wishing you all a wonderful and dirty spring day!
.
P.S. The recipe for these hibiscus lattes are up in the recipe archive at AdventuresInCooking.com!
.
.
.
.
.

posts.edge_media_to_caption:
Spent yesterday at a coffee farm in west Java with @nespresso where I learned all about the coffee growing and harvesting process. Each of these little red berries is a coffee cherry, and it grows on a shrub that thrives under the shade of a forest canopy. Inside each cherry are two little coffee beans, that eventually make their way into our homes + daily lives.
.
As a part of their partnership with the @nespresso AAA Sustainable Quality Program, local farmers have been given the financial means to help reforest the area, which has resulted in over 100,000 trees planted in Indonesia alone in the past 4 years. These trees help control climate change, and the erosion that takes place during the rainy season. The farmers we visited used organic methods of growing, like natural compost, & also grow produce mixed in with the coffee plants, since @nespresso encourages them to grow other produce as well so they have a steady income year round, and not just one big one during coffee harvest.
.
It's been incredible to see the long-term commitment and passion that the @nespresso team on the ground here has for empowering the local community & ensuring a safe and healthy environment for future generations‚Äîit makes me hopeful that perhaps other large companies will follow in their example. Because when you take care of the growers, it helps them and their families be able to flourish financially, it helps the earth where they live, it results in more delicious and high quality coffee, which then in turn supports them even more financially, and creates this incredible cycle of positivity and benefit for everyone involved. And that's something to toast your little espresso cup to! ‚òïÔ∏è #nespressotastemakers
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
#coffeeculture #coffeeoftheday #coffeesesh #cupsinframe #howiseemycoffee #igcoffee #instacoffee #vscocoffee#handsinframe #getpropped #eattheworld #firstweeat #eattheworld #heresmyfood #foodandwine #foodiegram #farmfresh #eatpretty #farmtofork

Yesterday I was on the longest flight of my life to date‚Äîwith the middle leg of the journey a non-stop 17 hour flight from San Francisco to Singapore. It was WILD stuff, guys. As someone who enjoys being busy and fluttering around from activity to activity, being confined in the same area for that amount of time is something else üòÇ
.
However, I do kind of like it when interesting constraints come up that trigger new ways to get creative. I'm always game for a challenge! So, I listened to a ton of podcasts, read a lot from the books I brought with me (one of which is about a hermit that lived in the wilderness of Maine for decades, it's crazy good!!), and got a lot of computer work done. Oh, and also slept. Like a lot. üëåüèΩ
.
But the important thing is that I made it! I'm here safe and sound in Indonesia and am so happy to see the jungle, all the beautiful plants and wildlife, and be surrounded by green. You can follow along in stories to see more of my adventure here, I'm so excited to share it with you! üòÜ
.
Wishing you all a wonderful week!!
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

I‚Äôm sharing the recipe for this delicious @BarillaUS Collezione bucatini carbonara up on the blog today in anticipation of World Carbonara Day on April 6th! If you‚Äôve never had it, I‚Äôm challenging you to make a big batch for yourself and take part in the fun and *insanely* tasty #CarbonaraChallenge with myself and Barilla. Joining the challenge is easy, simply make your favorite Carbonara recipe for your family and friends, post the dish on social media and challenge your friends to take the #CarbonaraChallenge, too! üí´
.
If you‚Äôre unfamiliar with carbonara, it‚Äôs a sauce made from freshly grated pecorino romano and parmesan cheeses, mixed with egg yolks (yep, it‚Äôs craaaazy good stuff) and freshly cracked black pepper to create a creamy, silky sauce that lightly coats each piece of bucatini pasta. üòã
.
Traditionally, it‚Äôs tossed with little pieces of thickly cut pancetta or prosciutto that have been pan-fried until crispy, which this recipe definitely has, but I added in one of my favorite pasta toppings to the mix, caramelized onions, for some sweetness, and some fresh basil leaves for a touch of bright fresh flavor. You can grab the recipe via the link in profile! üëÜüèº
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

Can't believe that spring is finally here in all it's green and pink beauty. üåøüå∏üåø The flowers are blooming in the garden, the hens are laying up a storm with all the extra daylight, and my favorite spring flavors are flooding the farmer's market. üëåüèº The only thing that's a little late is my rhubarb, which hasn't poked its head out of the garden.
.
My rhubarb *did* bloom last year, so I wonder if that had something to do with it? Maybe it reached the end of its life cycle. Or maybe the hens pecked its root stump to death during the fall and winter when they were free-ranging in the vegetable patch. üò¨ Both seems like definite possibilities!
.
In any case, I'm saying goodbye to spring today and heading off to Indonesia tonight where I'm sure to be greeted with sunshine much more intense than an Oregon summer. Plus humidity, too! But I'm a tough little bird, and I'll take the heat for some lush jungle scenery and coffee farm visits any day. üå¥üåûü•ù
.
.
.
.
.
.
